teaching_points: Renal artery stenosis causes renovascular hypertension
Blood pressure may improve significantly after revascularization
Perioperative BP control critical to prevent stroke or cardiac events
Hydration and minimize contrast to prevent kidney injury
Continue most antihypertensives perioperatively
Avoid ACE-I/ARBs on day of procedure due to vasoplegic syndrome risk
Adjust renally-cleared drugs for kidney function
Monitor for post-procedure hypertension or hypotension

anesthetic_considerations: MAC or conscious sedation typical
Aggressive pre-procedure hydration
Minimize contrast volume
Consider N-acetylcysteine or sodium bicarbonate for renal protection
Tight BP control throughout

teaching_points: Laryngectomy creates permanent tracheostomy with total airway separation
Shared airway requires coordination with surgeon throughout case
Hoarseness preoperatively indicates vocal cord involvement
Tumor may cause airway obstruction - have difficult airway equipment ready
Heavy smoking history increases COPD and CAD risk
Assess pulmonary function - may need postoperative ventilation
Cancer patients often malnourished affecting wound healing
Evaluate for airway distortion or stenosis from tumor
Consider awake fiberoptic intubation if airway compromise suspected
After laryngectomy, patient breathes through neck stoma permanently
Cannot bag-mask ventilate post-laryngectomy - ventilate via stoma
Humidified oxygen important postoperatively

anesthetic_considerations: Have difficult airway cart ready
Consider awake fiberoptic if tumor causes obstruction
TIVA vs inhalational based on surgeon preference
Avoid nitrous oxide (can expand air pockets)
Plan for tracheostomy at end of case
Postoperative humidified oxygen to stoma

teaching_points: Recurrent laryngeal nerve (RLN) injury risk in 1-2% of cases
Bilateral RLN injury causes airway obstruction from vocal cord adduction
Unilateral RLN injury causes hoarseness and aspiration risk
Nerve monitoring requires no or minimal neuromuscular blockade
Hypoparathyroidism occurs in 3-8% post-thyroidectomy
Hypocalcemia causes paresthesias, tetany, laryngospasm, seizures
Check calcium levels postoperatively - monitor Chvostek/Trousseau signs
Neck hematoma can cause airway compromise - emergent reopening needed
Assess for recurrent laryngeal nerve function before extubation
Perform cuff leak test to assess for airway edema
Have reintubation equipment immediately available
Watch for hematoma formation in PACU - can rapidly compromise airway

monitoring_needs: Nerve monitoring electrodes (EMG tube or surface)
anesthetic_considerations: Minimize or avoid muscle relaxants after intubation for nerve monitoring
Use EMG endotracheal tube or surface electrodes
Head extension positioning - shoulder roll
Smooth emergence to prevent coughing/straining
Awake extubation with full return of airway reflexes
Reintubation equipment at bedside postoperatively

surgical_type: ENT - Mandibulectomy with free flap reconstruction

teaching_points: Mandibulectomy with reconstruction is lengthy surgery (8-12 hours)
Free flap requires meticulous blood pressure and perfusion management
Microvascular anastomoses sensitive to vasospasm - avoid hypothermia
Alcohol use increases withdrawal, bleeding, and healing complications
Chronic alcohol use causes thiamine deficiency, cardiomyopathy, coagulopathy
Oral cancer patients often malnourished affecting healing
Tumor may cause difficult airway - limited mouth opening, tissue distortion
Assess for airway bleeding or secretions
Tracheostomy typically performed for airway protection postoperatively
Maintain MAP 65-80 mmHg for flap perfusion
Avoid vasoconstrictors if possible to preserve flap blood flow
Temperature control critical - hypothermia causes vasoconstriction

anesthetic_considerations: Awake fiberoptic intubation if difficult airway anticipated
Tracheostomy performed at end of case
Aggressive warming measures - forced air warmer, fluid warmer
Goal MAP 65-80 mmHg for flap perfusion
Liberal fluid resuscitation for long case
Plan for postoperative ICU admission with mechanical ventilation

teaching_points: FESS requires bloodless field for optimal surgical visualization
Mild hypotension (MAP 60-70) reduces bleeding but must maintain perfusion
Head-up positioning (reverse Trendelenburg) decreases venous congestion
Throat pack placement prevents blood in stomach and reduces PONV
Chronic sinusitis often associated with asthma and nasal polyps
Aspirin sensitivity triad: asthma, nasal polyps, aspirin sensitivity
Optimize asthma control preoperatively
Avoid NSAIDs if aspirin-sensitive
Controlled hypotension techniques: propofol, remifentanil, beta-blockers
Avoid coughing/bucking on extubation to prevent bleeding
Smooth deep extubation vs awake extubation decision
Confirm throat pack removed before extubation

anesthetic_considerations: Total IV anesthesia (TIVA) with propofol and remifentanil preferred
Controlled hypotension with MAP 60-70 mmHg
Reverse Trendelenburg positioning 10-15 degrees
Throat pack placement and documentation
Dexamethasone for polyps and PONV prevention
Smooth emergence - consider deep extubation in well-controlled asthmatic

teaching_points: UPPP creates significant pharyngeal and palatal edema postoperatively
OSA patients have difficult airway - redundant tissue, large tongue, narrow pharynx
High risk of postoperative airway obstruction and desaturation
STOP-Bang score guides severity assessment
OSA increases risk of difficult mask ventilation and intubation
Obesity compounds OSA effects - reduced FRC, increased oxygen consumption
Postoperative opioids dangerous in OSA - respiratory depression
CPAP therapy should be optimized preoperatively and resumed immediately postop
Perform cuff leak test before extubation to assess edema
Extubate fully awake, sitting up, with full airway reflexes
Multimodal analgesia to minimize opioids - acetaminophen, NSAIDs, dexamethasone
Reintubation equipment and personnel must be immediately available

anesthetic_considerations: Ramped positioning for intubation
Video laryngoscopy available
Minimize opioids - use multimodal analgesia
Dexamethasone 8-10 mg IV for airway edema prevention
Cuff leak test before extubation
Fully awake extubation in semi-Fowler position
CPAP immediately postoperatively
Extended PACU monitoring or ICU admission

teaching_points: Facial nerve (CN VII) runs through parotid gland - injury causes facial paralysis
Nerve monitoring requires no muscle relaxation after intubation
Monitor facial nerve integrity with EMG - watch for surgeon alerts
Patient positioning lateral with head turned - protect eyes and pressure points
Parotid tumors usually benign (80%) but can be malignant
Hypertension increases bleeding risk - optimize BP control
Proximity to carotid artery and jugular vein
Consider facial nerve dysfunction if pre-existing weakness
Complete reversal of neuromuscular blockade essential
TOF ratio >0.9 required for safe extubation
PONV prophylaxis important - head/neck surgery high risk
Smooth emergence to prevent bleeding from hypertension/coughing

anesthetic_considerations: Avoid or minimize muscle relaxants after intubation
Use short-acting agents if relaxation needed (rocuronium with sugammadex available)
Maintain adequate anesthetic depth without relaxation
Multimodal PONV prophylaxis
Smooth emergence - control blood pressure
Full reversal confirmed before extubation

teaching_points: Glossectomy causes significant airway changes - tongue essential for patency
Partial glossectomy may allow extubation; total requires tracheostomy
Airway obstruction risk from tongue swelling and loss of anatomy
Aspiration risk very high postoperatively
Smoking history increases oral cancer risk and COPD
Tongue tumor can cause difficult intubation - distorted anatomy
Cancer patients often malnourished and cachexic
Assess for airway bleeding or secretions
Consider awake fiberoptic intubation if tumor causes obstruction
Topical anesthesia and careful sedation for awake intubation
Plan for tracheostomy at end of case for airway protection
ICU admission with mechanical ventilation expected

anesthetic_considerations: Awake fiberoptic intubation likely needed
Have emergency airway equipment ready
Plan for tracheostomy at end of case
NG tube placement for nutrition postoperatively
ICU admission with mechanical ventilation
Consider free flap if reconstruction - maintain perfusion pressure

teaching_points: Prior radiation causes tissue fibrosis, reduced mouth opening, friable tissue
Difficult mask ventilation and intubation from radiation changes
Tissue bleeds easily - gentle laryngoscopy essential
Edema from impaired lymphatic drainage
Document radiation dose, timing, and field
Assess mouth opening, neck mobility, tissue quality
Previous radiation is major difficult airway predictor
Friable tissue increases bleeding risk during laryngoscopy
Awake fiberoptic intubation safest approach
Topicalize airway thoroughly - antisialagogue helpful
Gentle technique to avoid tissue trauma and bleeding
Have difficult airway cart and backup plans ready

anesthetic_considerations: Awake fiberoptic intubation strongly recommended
Glycopyrrolate for antisialagogue
Topical anesthesia to airway - careful sedation
Video laryngoscopy as backup
Gentle technique throughout
Plan for possible bleeding - have suction ready

teaching_points: Vocal cord paralysis causes hoarseness and aspiration risk
Unilateral paralysis impairs glottic closure - aspiration of liquids
GERD worsens aspiration risk - full stomach precautions
Vocal cord injection medializes cord to improve voice and swallowing
GERD increases aspiration risk - consider RSI
Aspiration history indicates incompetent airway protection
Extended NPO time may be appropriate
Aspiration prophylaxis: H2-blocker, proton pump inhibitor, metoclopramide
Consider RSI for aspiration risk from GERD and vocal cord dysfunction
Short procedure - may use LMA or ETT based on aspiration risk
Surgeon needs access to vocal cords via laryngoscopy
Coordinate with surgeon for airway access

anesthetic_considerations: Aspiration prophylaxis - consider H2-blocker, metoclopramide
RSI vs standard induction based on aspiration risk assessment
ETT vs LMA decision based on risk factors
Coordinate with surgeon for airway sharing
Awake extubation with full airway reflexes
Monitor for aspiration postoperatively

teaching_points: Acoustic neuroma (vestibular schwannoma) arises from CN VIII
Surgery risks damage to CN VII (facial), CN VIII (hearing), CN V (facial sensation)
Posterior fossa approach - lateral/semi-sitting positioning
Long surgery (6-12 hours) with significant physiologic stress
Assess baseline facial nerve function (CN VII)
Document hearing loss severity (CN VIII already affected)
Evaluate for hydrocephalus or brainstem compression
Elderly patient - assess cardiac and cerebrovascular disease
Facial nerve EMG monitoring requires no muscle relaxation
BAER (brainstem auditory evoked responses) monitors CN VIII and brainstem
Lateral position risks brachial plexus injury - careful arm positioning
Venous air embolism risk in semi-sitting position - precordial Doppler monitoring

anesthetic_considerations: Avoid muscle relaxants after intubation for nerve monitoring
TIVA preferred for reliable neuromonitoring
Careful positioning - lateral or semi-sitting based on surgeon preference
Venous air embolism precautions if semi-sitting
Maintain cerebral perfusion pressure
Plan for postoperative ICU monitoring
Consider facial nerve paralysis postoperatively
